question.body: Which of these enzymes is produced and secreted into one section of the GI tract, but not active until it reaches another section?

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is active in the mouth and inactivated by the stomach pH.
Incorrect. This is secreted and active in the small intestine.
Correct. Saliva is maintained at low acidity and this enzyme needs to be activated by the acidic contents of the stomach.
Incorrect. This is secreted and active in the stomach lumen

part.hint: This is produced and secreted in a low acidity (high pH) area, but is active only at high acidity (low pH).

body.p: Which chemical is produced and secreted into the GI tract to help buffer and maintain high pH for proper enzyme activity?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Mucus forms a mucosal barrier that protects the tissues from stomach acid, but it doesn’t buffer the pH of the stomach contents.
Correct. Bicarbonate ions in both saliva and pancreatic juice help maintain a slightly alkaline pH for the many enzymes that don’t function at low pH.
Incorrect. Bile salts emulsify lipids but don’t affect the pH of the GI tract contents.
Incorrect. Intrinsic Factor is produced in the stomach and assists proper absorption of vitamin B 12 in the small intestine, but doesn’t affect the pH.

part.hint: This is produced and secreted in both saliva and pancreatic juice.
